document.text: The experiment includes a comparison of different models:
This model only takes as inputs the
past trajectories of the agents in the scene and outputs
trajectories with their associated probabilities (see the
architecture in the red rectangle in Fig. 1). We use
model a radial grid representation from which we
extract potential goals. We predict the goal and then
the trajectories conditioned on the predicted goal. (see
the architecture in the orange rectangle in Fig. 1).
To predict the goal of the
target agent, we combine the DCM and the neural
network using the LMNL framework [15]. This model is
described in Section III and the architecture is illustrated
in the blue rectangle in Fig. 1.

For the second DCM, the utility function
, we use the same mathematical formula
as the occupancy function in (IV-C), however, we
don’t consider the position of the neighbors at time
. Instead, we consider their predicted position at
using a Constant velocity model. We
assume that before predicting his goal, the target agent
first predicts the future positions of his surroundings
according to their headings and current velocitites,
and then avoids the zones that are expected to be
crowded. While training this model, we calculate the
function using the grouth truth positions of the
number of potential goals. Similar to [8],
our interaction space is 40 m ahead of the target vehicle,
10 m behind and 25 m on each side. We consider the
neighbors situated in the interaction space at
take into account the neighbors that are susceptible of being
the trajectories of all of the neighbors in the scene using a
Constant Velocity model and if they have a predicted position
in the interaction space, we consider them in our model. We
argue that this representation allows to consider neighbors
that are not situated in the grid at
having to create a bigger interaction space which can be
parallel attention operations. We use a batch size of 64 and
Adam optimizer. The model is implemented using PyTorch
Our method for trajectory forecasting is evaluated with the
: The average of pointwise L2 distances
between the predicted trajectory and ground truth over
: The final displacement error (FDE) is the
L2 distance between the final points of the prediction
and ground truth. We take the minimum FDE over the
k most likely predictions and average over all agents.
This metric calculates the percentage of collision
between the primary vehicle’s prediction and the
neighbors in the groundtruth future scene.
We compare the methods described in Section IV-B.
The results are reported in Table I. DCM
refers to the first (resp the second) type of DCM described

the dynamic radial grid representation for the extraction of
potential goals. We can see that adding the DCM module
decrease the percentage of collisions. We can see that the
